Issues.Title: Logitech mouse scrolling causes exception
Issues.Body:
Hi, we've had multiple customers using a Logitech mouse report crashes lately with this stack:

```
OverflowException: Arithmetic operation resulted in an overflow.
   at System.Windows.Shell.WindowChromeWorker._HandleNCHitTest(WM uMsg, IntPtr wParam, IntPtr lParam, Boolean& handled)
   at System.Windows.Shell.WindowChromeWorker._WndProc(IntPtr hwnd, Int32 msg, IntPtr wParam, IntPtr lParam, Boolean& handled)
```

It sounds like it is a Logitech driver bug that isn't well handled by .NET.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50282355/why-does-my-wpf-application-crash-when-i-bump-my-mousewheel
https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/overflow-exception-in-windowchrome/167357

“WPF applications which are built for x64 and use the WindowChrome class throw an OverflowException when receiving a horizontal scroll command from a Logitech mouse configured with SetPoint.”
“It seems like a bad assumption is made in Standard.Utility that lParams always fit in 32 bits, and some mouse drivers violate that on 64-bit systems by writing there.”

The developer community issue was closed long ago, but we recently updated to .NET 6 and started getting customer reports (although we have not been able to determine how to repro it locally). The developer community post has a suggested workaround, but it's a fairly ugly workaround to add so we'd like to see about getting a fix in .NET.

Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Logitech mouse scrolling causes exception" (#7882)

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WPF_EditExaminer_Color Contrast: The non-text color contrast between the keyboard focus and its background for "No exception! Warning Box" is 2.296:1 which is < 3:1
Issues.Body:
### Description

“[Check out Accessibility Insights!](https://accessibilityinsights.io/) - Identify accessibility bugs before check-in and make bug fixing faster and easier.”

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[WPF]_Win32_May23;#.NET Core;#A11ySev2;#A11yWCAG2.1;#WCAG1.4.11;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#Non-Text contrast;#Benchmark;

### Environment Details:
Application Name: .NET Core
WPF
Operating System: Windows 11 Enterprise 21H2

### Reproduction Steps

1. Launch VS 2022 Preview
2. Navigate to Sample Applications and right click on the "Editing Examiner Demo" and click on build.
3. Then right click on Editing Examiner Demo then Click on Debug-->Start New Instance.
4. "Edit Examiner" screen should open.
5. TAB to "No exception! Warning Box".
6. Verify whether the non-text color contrast between the keyboard focus and its background for "No exception! Warning Box" is 2.296:1 which is < 3:1 or not.

### Expected behavior

 The non-text color contrast between the keyboard focus and its background for "No exception! Warning Box" should be >= 3:1

### Actual behavior

The non-text color contrast between the keyboard focus and its background for "No exception! Warning Box" is 2.296:1 which is less than 3:1.

![A11y_ NET Core_WPF_EditExaminer_Color Contrast](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/91525824/aa70757a-745b-45c8-80f3-b329f991f1ab)


### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Impact

Low vision users won't be able to recognize the focus if it fails the minimum non-text color contrast ratio of 3:1.

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_

Issues.Title: Thumbnail not correctly stored by Microsoft JPEG Encoder
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Thumbnail-not-correctly-stored-by-Micros/1587311)._

---
Saving an Image by the Microsoft JPEG Encoder stores the Thumbnail incorrectly (APP1 Exif Entry).

Wrong produced by JPEG Encoder (JPEG Image File):

FF D8 FF E0 00 10 4A 46 49 46 00 01 01 01 00 60 
00 60 00 00 FF E1 0C 40 45 78 69 66 00 00 4D 4D
 00 2A 00 00 00 08 00 00 00 00 **00 0E** 00 06 01 03 
00 03 00 00 00 01 00 06 00 00 01 1A 00 05 00 00
 00 01 00 00 00 5C 01 1B 00 05 00 00 00 01 00 00 
00 64 01 28 00 03 00 00 00 01 00 02 00 00 02 01 
00 04 00 00 00 01 00 00 00 6C 02 02 00 04 00 00
 00 01 00 00 0B CC 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 60 00 00
 00 01 00 00 00 60 00 00 00 01 FF D8 FF DB 00 43
...
The TIFF tag countfield 000E should be at address X'26" instead of X'2A'

Preceding image was produced by following program:

Private Sub Button_Click(sender As Object, e As RoutedEventArgs)
        Dim file1 As String
        Dim file2 As String
        Dim dec1 As BitmapDecoder
        Dim enc1 As JpegBitmapEncoder
        Dim stream1 As System.IO.FileStream
        Dim stream2 As System.IO.FileStream
        Dim bmp1 As BitmapSource
        Dim bmp2 As BitmapSource    '   Thumbnail
        Dim transform1 As ScaleTransform
        Dim frame1 As BitmapFrame

file1 = "d:\testfiles\jpeg\MM Jpeg.jpg"
        stream1 = New System.IO.FileStream(file1, IO. FileMode.Open, IO. FileAccess.Read)
        dec1 = BitmapDecoder.Create(stream1, Nothing, Nothing)
        bmp1 = dec1. Frames(0)

transform1 = New ScaleTransform
        transform1. ScaleX = 0.125
        transform1. ScaleY = 0.125
        bmp2 = New TransformedBitmap(bmp1, transform1)

enc1 = New JpegBitmapEncoder
        enc1. QualityLevel = 75

file2 = "d:\temp\MM JPEG created by JPEGencoder.jpg"
        stream2 = New System.IO.FileStream(file2, IO. FileMode.Create, IO. FileAccess.Write)
        frame1 = BitmapFrame.Create(bmp1, bmp2, Nothing, Nothing)
        enc1. Frames.Add(frame1)
        enc1. Save(stream2)
        stream2. Close()

End Sub

Correct example:

FF D8 FF E0 00 10 4A 46 49 46 00 01 02 01 00 60
 00 60 00 00 FF E1 0D CC 45 78 69 66 00 00 4D 4D
 00 2A 00 00 00 08 00 07 01 12 00 03 00 00 00 01
 00 01 00 00 01 1A 00 05 00 00 00 01 00 00 00 62
 01 1B 00 05 00 00 00 01 00 00 00 6A 01 28 00 03
 00 00 00 01 00 02 00 00 01 31 00 02 00 00 00 1B
 00 00 00 72 01 32 00 02 00 00 00 14 00 00 00 8D
 87 69 00 04 00 00 00 01 00 00 00 A4 00 00 00 D0
 00 00 00 60 00 00 00 01 00 00 00 60 00 00 00 01
 41 64 6F 62 65 20 50 68 6F 74 6F 73 68 6F 70 20 
43 53 20 57 69 6E 64 6F 77 73 00 32 30 30 35 3A 
31 31 3A 31 35 20 30 30 3A 31 32 3A 32 37 00 00
 00 00 00 03 A0 01 00 03 00 00 00 01 FF FF 00 00
...

Issues.Title: System.Windows.Media.Imaging 'Cannot write to the stream'
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/SystemWindowsMediaImaging-Cannot-wri/1030948)._

---
I have a TIF file which measures 28" wide by 170" high at 400dpi with CCITT4 compression.  It was created using classes/functions in the System.Windows.Media.Imaging namespace.  I'm trying to rotate it by 90 degrees and save the resulting image.  The encoder seems to write for a while, then gives the error  'Cannot write to the stream'.  It does this for memory stream or file stream. I'm running VS2017 and I have a subscription through my employer, but it is not at all obvious how I would open a support case with Microsoft.  It would be helpful to have a link like that in VS.  Anyway, the image is of our company's IP so I can't just randomly post the image.  Other images seem to have the same problem.

Issues.Title: System.Windows.Markup.XamlParseException provides no file name
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity2.visualstudio.com/t/SystemWindowsMarkupXamlParseException/1049255)._

---
It is very difficult to locate the root of an "System.Windows.Markup.XamlParseException" at rumtime. The position in the file is in the exception message but the file name ist missing. This is even more difficult if the problem is located in one of the merged dictionaries. Then the Exception doesn't pop up in the constructor of the control but as "Application is in a break mode" with no useful call stack at all.

**Exception details:**

Issues.Title: ShowDialog bug on touchscreen c# wpf datagrid
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/ShowDialog-bug-on-touchscreen-c-wpf-dat/1660656)._

---
[severity:It bothers me. A fix would be nice]
I have:
<DataGrid ItemsSource="{Binding}" AutoGenerateColumns="False">
	<DataGrid.Columns>
		<DataGridTextColumn Header="Имя параметра" IsReadOnly="True" Binding="{Binding Name}" MinWidth="300"/>

<DataGridTemplateColumn Header="Значение" MinWidth="60" IsReadOnly="False">
			<DataGridTemplateColumn.CellTemplate>
				<DataTemplate>
					<TextBlock Text="{Binding Data.Value}" Style="{StaticResource TextBlockCustom}"/>
				</DataTemplate>
			</DataGridTemplateColumn.CellTemplate>
			<DataGridTemplateColumn.CellEditingTemplate>
				<DataTemplate>
					<TextBlock Text="{Binding Data.Value}" Style="{StaticResource TextBlockCustom}">
						<i:Interaction.Triggers>
							<i:EventTrigger EventName="Loaded">
								<i:InvokeCommandAction Command="{Binding ElementName=this, Path=DataContext.Item.CellEditCommand}" CommandParameter="{Binding Data.ID}"/>
							</i:EventTrigger>
							<i:EventTrigger EventName="PreviewMouseLeftButtonDown">
								<i:InvokeCommandAction Command="{Binding ElementName=this, Path=DataContext.Item.CellEditCommand}" CommandParameter="{Binding Data.ID}"/>
							</i:EventTrigger>
						</i:Interaction.Triggers>
					</TextBlock>
				</DataTemplate>
			</DataGridTemplateColumn.CellEditingTemplate>
		</DataGridTemplateColumn>
	</DataGrid.Columns>
</DataGrid>

The code leads to the method:
bool GetNewValue(double aOldValue, out double Result)
            {
                InputWindow inputWindow = new InputWindow(aOldValue);
                
inputWindow.ShowDialog();
                if (inputWindow.DialogResult == true)
                {
                    Result = inputWindow.Value;
                    return true;
                }
                
Result = 0.0;
                return false;
            }

When the previously edited cell is called again, the inputWindow opens, but does not respond to several commands from the touch screen. inputWindow responds immediately to commands from the mouse. I tried replacing the DataGrid with a ListBox, but the result remained the same. For some reason, events from the touch screen are not linked.
The problem is hidden in the operation of the method: . ShowDialog()

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WPF_EditExaminer_ScreenReader: Narrator is not announcing the tooltip information for "Immediate Window", "Type command here", "No exception" control.
Issues.Body:
### Description

“[Check out Accessibility Insights!](https://accessibilityinsights.io/) - Identify accessibility bugs before check-in and make bug fixing faster and easier.”

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[WPF]_Win32_May23;#.NET Core;#A11ySev2;#WCAG1.3.1;#Narrator;#NVDA;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#Element:Tooltip;#Screen Reader;#Benchmark;

### Environment Details:
Application Name: .NET Core
WPF
Operating System: Windows 11 Enterprise 21H2

### Reproduction Steps

1. Launch VS 2022 Preview
2. Navigate to Sample Applications and right click on the "Editing Examiner Demo" and click on build.
3. Then right click on Editing Examiner Demo then Click on Debug-->Start New Instance.
4. "Edit Examiner" screen should open.
5. Turn on Narrator.
6. TAB to "Immediate Window", "Type command here", "No exception" control.
7. Check whether Narrator is announcing the tooltip information for "Immediate Window", "Type command here", "No exception" control or not.

### Expected behavior

The tooltip information for "Immediate Window", "Type command here", "No exception" control should be read by screen reader.

### Actual behavior

Narrator is not announcing the tooltip information for "Immediate Window", "Type command here", "No exception" control.

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Impact

Screen reader users may not know the extra information which is provided in tooltip, and they will face difficulty in knowing the extra information about the control as screen reader is not announcing the tooltip information.

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "A11y_.NET Core_WPF_EditExaminer_ScreenReader: Narrator is not announcing the tooltip information for "Immediate Window", "Type command here", "No exception" control." (#7874)

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WPF_EditExaminer_ImmediateWindow_Resize: At 200% zoom, "Immediate Window" control name is getting truncated.
Issues.Body:
### Description

“[Check out Accessibility Insights!](https://accessibilityinsights.io/) - Identify accessibility bugs before check-in and make bug fixing faster and easier.”

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[WPF]_Win32_May23;#.NET Core;#A11ySev2;#WCAG1.4.4;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#Zoom;#Benchmark;

### Environment Details:
Application Name: .NET Core
WPF
Operating System: Windows 11 Enterprise 21H2

### Reproduction Steps

1. Launch VS 2022 Preview
2. Navigate to Sample Applications and right click on the "Editing Examiner Demo" and click on build.
3. Then right click on Editing Examiner Demo then Click on Debug-->Start New Instance. 
4. "Edit Examiner" screen should open.
5. Zoom the screen to 200% using Text Size and observe that "Immediate Window" control name is getting truncated in 200% zoom.

### Expected behavior

At 200% zoom, "Immediate Window" control name should not get truncated. "Immediate Window" text should completely visible.

### Actual behavior

At 200% zoom, "Immediate Window" control name is getting truncated. The text is not completely visible.

![A11y_ NET Core_WPF_EditExaminer_ImmediateWindow_Resize](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/91525824/db8caa48-31af-4ea8-ad8c-9d67089dbd6e)


### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Impact

Users with low vision who zoom the page for better visibility will face difficulty in understanding what is the title of the Control if "Immediate Window" text is not visible.

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_

Issues.Title: Provide DX12 WPF island
Issues.Body:
DX12 windows are interesting for performance (speed, latency, colors etc), bringing for instance higher colors depth, HDR, and extremely low latency for display to WPF framework.

I am doing so "by hand", involving actual c code for D3D12 and c-c# interop to provide integration, but it involve a lot of work/code for connection, sizing, injection into a XAML content, interop.

Something more standardized and implemented could be a great thing and could bring many new possibilities to WPF and to a broader audience of developers and users.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Provide DX12 WPF island " (#7871)

Issues.Title: Custom ShaderEffect does not work in DrawingVisual or background control rendering
Issues.Body:
### Description

I am trying out custom shaders to develop a tool for modifying image brightness and saturation
like this：
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/23449064/4de2d4cb-7c7a-44e6-9668-a2da50c93b44)
You can import an image, modify the slider in the bottom right corner, and then click the save button to save it to a file
>>>
Fortunately, by sliding two sliders in the form, the image has brightness and saturation changes, 
**Unfortunately, The saved image does not have any additional effects**

After various attempts, I have found that the built-in Effect of WPF can operate normally, but the custom ShaderEffect does not work. It seems to have done some different rendering operations on the interface

### Reproduction Steps

1,xaml：
```xml
 <Grid>
        <Grid.RowDefinitions>
            <RowDefinition Height="50" />
            <RowDefinition />
            <RowDefinition Height="50" />
        </Grid.RowDefinitions>
        <Button
            Grid.Row="0"
            Click="Load_Click"
            Content="Load Image" />

        <Image x:Name="image" Grid.Row="1">
            <Image.Effect>
                <shader:IntensitySaturationEffect
                    BaseIntensity="{Binding ElementName=sliderIntensity, Path=Value}"
                    BaseSaturation="1"
                    BloomIntensity="1"
                    BloomSaturation="{Binding ElementName=sliderSaturation, Path=Value}" />
            </Image.Effect>
        </Image>

        <Grid Grid.Row="2">
            <WrapPanel HorizontalAlignment="Left" VerticalAlignment="Center">
                <TextBlock Text="Intensity:" />
                <Slider
                    x:Name="sliderIntensity"
                    Width="100"
                    Maximum="1"
                    Minimum="0"
                    Value="0.5" />
                <TextBlock Text="Saturation:" />
                <Slider
                    x:Name="sliderSaturation"
                    Width="100"
                    Maximum="2"
                    Minimum="0"
                    Value="1" />
            </WrapPanel>
            <Button
                Margin="10,0"
                Padding="10"
                HorizontalAlignment="Right"
                VerticalAlignment="Center"
                Click="Save_Click"
                Content="Save" />
        </Grid>
    </Grid>
```
2,C#
```C#
private void Load_Click(object sender, RoutedEventArgs e) {
            OpenFileDialog openFileDialog = new OpenFileDialog();
            if (openFileDialog.ShowDialog().Value) {
                var bitmapImage = new BitmapImage(new Uri(openFileDialog.FileName));
                image.Source = bitmapImage;
            }
        }

        private void Save_Click(object sender, RoutedEventArgs e) {
            DrawingVisual dv = new DrawingVisual() {
                Effect = image.Effect
            };
            using (DrawingContext dc = dv.RenderOpen()) {
                dc.DrawImage(image.Source, new Rect(0, 0, image.Source.Width, image.Source.Height));
            }
            var renderTargetBitmap = new RenderTargetBitmap((int)image.Source.Width, (int)image.Source.Height, 96, 96, PixelFormats.Pbgra32);
            renderTargetBitmap.Render(dv);

            SaveFileDialog saveFileDialog = new SaveFileDialog();
            if (saveFileDialog.ShowDialog().Value) {
                using (var fileStream = new System.IO.FileStream(saveFileDialog.FileName, System.IO.FileMode.Create)) {
                    var encoder = new PngBitmapEncoder();
                    encoder.Frames.Add(BitmapFrame.Create(renderTargetBitmap));
                    encoder.Save(fileStream);
                }
            }
        }
```
3.Comparing UI and Files(The left side shows the saved results, and the right side shows the UI display)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/23449064/fad0dcbe-869d-44b0-b21c-301f5edeb47b)


### Expected behavior

UI and file consistency

### Actual behavior

UI and file inconsistency

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

No solution
The methods I have tried:
Using the DropShadowEffect that comes with WPF    √

But WPF does not have its own saturation brightness effect......

### Impact

_No response_

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

I have uploaded the code to github：https://github.com/BigHeadDev/CustomShaderEffectTest

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WPF_DatabindingDemo_ListofProducts_Add product listing_Resize: In 200% zoom, the content under "Item for sale" are getting truncated.
Issues.Body:
### Description


“[Check out Accessibility Insights!](https://accessibilityinsights.io/) - Identify accessibility bugs before check-in and make bug fixing faster and easier.”

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[WPF]_Win32_May23;#.NET Core;#A11ySev2;#WCAG1.4.4;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#Zoom;#Benchmark;

### Environment Details:
Application Name: .NET Core
WPF
Operating System: Windows 11 Enterprise 21H2

### Reproduction Steps

1. Launch VS 2022 Preview
2. TAB to Sample Applications and right-click on the "DatabindingDemo" and click on build.
3. Then right click on "DatabindingDemo" then Click on Debug-->Start New Instance.
4. "List of products" screen should open.
5. TAB to "Add product" button and click on it.
6. Zoom the screen to 200% and observe that the content under "Item for sale" are getting truncated in 200% zoom.

### Expected behavior

In 200% zoom, the content under "Item for sale" should not getting truncated. All the contents should completely visible.

### Actual behavior

In 200% zoom, the content under "Item for sale" are getting truncated. The texts are not completely visible.

![A11y_ NET Core_WPF_DatabindingDemo_ListofProducts_Add product listing_Resize](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/91525824/3a776239-0ffc-4d2a-ade7-e4bbd96d7a89)


### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

_No response_

### Impact

Users with low vision who zoom the page for better visibility will face difficulty if the content of "Item for sale" are getting truncated.

### Configuration

_No response_

### Other information

_No response_

Issues.Title: View used AllowsTransparency And DropShadowEffect Causing UI Stuck
Issues.Body:
There is a WPF program using CM Framework 3.2. I have a replay.xaml page that displays two images and two timestamp texts every 30ms to play back videos in a modal manner.
When using the AllowsTransparency and DropShadowEffect properties on the page, opening multiple replay.xaml pages can cause the UI to refresh slowly and become sluggish.
After I delete the relevant code of AllowsTransparency and DropShadowEffect only in replay.xaml, opening multiple replay.xaml pages will not cause the UI to become sluggish.
My display settings in the code are:
AllowsTransparency = True;
Grid.Effect>
DropShadowEffect ShadowDepth="0"
BlurRadius="5"
Opacity="0.9" />
Grid.Effect>
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "View used AllowsTransparency And DropShadowEffect Causing UI Stuck" (#7857)
